segments.text: You're the only one I know who loves his parents.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I know.  It went out of style, didn't it?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It's okay.  It's a good thing.  You know, it's lovely here and the air is sweet.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: So you're not sorry you came?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: No, not sorry, but I'm not going to stay.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Why?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: In the first place, your mother as much as told me to go.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You saw that and then you've been kind of--
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: What?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well, kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: The trouble is I planned on sneaking up on you over a period of a week or so.  But they take it for granted that we're all set.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I knew they would, your mother, anyway.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: How did you know?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: From her point of view, why else would I come?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well wouldn't you want to?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I guess you know this is why I asked you to come.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I guess this is why I came.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I have no imagination.  That's all I know to tell you.  I'm embarrassing you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I didn't want to tell it to you here.  I wanted someplace we'd never been; someplace where we'd be brand new to each other.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You think this is wrong, don't you; this yard, this chair?  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to win you away from anything.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long time.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Then he's gone forever?  You're sure?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I almost got married two years ago.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Why didn't you?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You started to write me.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: You felt something that far back?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Every day since.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Anne, why didn't you let me know?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  'Til then, you never wrote and when you did, what did you say?  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Anne, give me a kiss.  Give me a -
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I kissed you.  I kissed Annie.  How long, how long I've waited to kiss you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  All I've done is sit around and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Anne, we're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Not like that you're not.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I kissed you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.  What is it, Chris?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Let's drive somewhere.  I want to be alone with you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: No, what is it, Chris?  Your mother?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: No, no, nothing like that.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Then what's wrong.  Even in your letters, there was something ashamed.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yes, I suppose there has been.  But it's going from me.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You've got to tell me.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't know where to start.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: It wouldn't work this way.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: It's all mixed up with so many other things.  You remember overseas, I was in command of a company?
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Yeah, sure.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Well I lost them.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: How many?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Just about all.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Oh, gees.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: It takes a little time to toss that off because they weren't just men.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: For instance, one time it'd been raining several days.  And this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks; put them in my pocket.  That's only a little thing, but that's the kind of guys I had.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: They didn't die.  They killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  A little more selfish and they'd have been here today.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: And I got this idea watching them go down, everything was being destroyed, see?  But, to me, it seemed there was one new thing that was made,
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: a kind of responsibility.  Man for man.  You understand me?  And then I went home and it was incredible.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: There was no meaning in it here.  The whole thing to them was some sort of bus accident.  Then I went to work for dad and that whole rat race again.  I felt, what you said, ashamed somehow
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: because nobody was changed.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive;
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: to open that bank book; to drive the new car; to see the new refrigerator.  I mean, you can take these things out of a war, but when you drive the new car, you have to know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You have to be a little better because of that.  Otherwise, we have is really loot and there's blood on it.  I don't want to take any of it.  I guess that included you.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: And do you still feel that way?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I want you now, Annie.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Because you mustn't feel that way anymore, Chris.  Because you have a right to everything you have, everything, Chris; to me, too.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: And your money, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes in the air.  You should be proud.  A man should be paid for that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Annie, Annie, I'm going to make you a fortune.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: What'll I do with a fortune?
segments.speaker: F
